title-group.article-title: Easy Grasp: A novel hybrid-driven manual medical instrument for laparoscopic surgery

article-meta.aff: Key Laboratory for Mechanism Theory and Equipment Design of the Ministry of Education, School of Mechanical Engineering, Tianjin University, PR China

author-notes.corresp: Xiaofei Wang, Key Laboratory for Mechanism Theory and Equipment Design of the Ministry of Education, School of Mechanical Engineering, Tianjin University, 92 Weijin Road, Nankai District, Tianjin 300072, PR China. Email: wangfifi@msn.com

abstract.p: A novel compact manual instrument for laparoscopic surgery, Easy Grasp, is proposed and the prototype is developed. It is a hybridization of cable and link drives. The instrument conforms to the ergonomic engineering and it can realize roll, pitch, and yaw motions. Owing to the parallelograms and universal joints, the motions outside the abdomen can be mapped to the end-effector motions inside the abdomen exactly. The workspace of the wrist-like joint is a submanifold of special orthogonal group and is evaluated by the matrix exponential parameterization. The structure of the instrument is designed optimally on the basis of the kinematic analysis together with the global condition index. The instrument can not only satisfy the needs of basic tasks, but also be used to accomplish difficult tasks such as suturing and knot-tying. Experimental results show that the instrument works as well as commercial products. The ease of use will make the instrument effective in laparoscopic surgery. The structure of the instrument is a prototype for other manual instruments and provides a framework for instrument design.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Laparoscopic surgery is a modern surgical technique. During the surgery, only a few small incisions (5-15 mm in diameter) in the abdomen are made and surgeons operate with long slender medical instruments through the incision points. Nowadays, laparoscopic surgery becomes more and more popular. Compared with conventional open surgery, laparoscopic surgery has the advantages of less operative trauma (pain and scarring), smaller incisions, and shorter hospitalization time. However, due to intrinsic constraints of the incision points, disadvantages to perform laparoscopic surgery using conventional instruments still exist, such as limited vision, restricted mobility, and difficult handling.1–4

With the development of technology, robotic surgery has appeared as a new category of surgery. Surgical robots can improve operating dexterity, locating precision, and hand-eye coordination in surgery and thus they have been widely used in hospitals.5–7 Meanwhile, manual instruments are simultaneously used in the robotic surgery. For some simple surgeries, robots are not needed due to the long set-up time. Therefore, it is desirable to develop multi-DoF (degree of freedom) manual instruments to facilitate laparoscopic surgery.

In laparoscopic surgery, dexterity of surgeons is reduced because the DoF of conventional manual instruments drops from six to four (Figure 1(a)) due to the constraint of the incision point. Despite being light-weight and inexpensive, the conventional manual instruments make the surgeon perform some tasks clumsily. In order to enhance dexterity, two extra rotational DoFs (pitch and yaw motions) are needed, as shown in Figure 1(b). Figure 1.
DoFs for conventional and multi-DoF instrument.

According to the structure which can realize pitch and yaw motions, the instrument can be classified into the following three categories: (a) three joints with intersecting axes,8,9 (b) multi-slider linkages,10,11 and (c) spherical joints.12 Some more examples, Awtar et al.,13 using the first structure, proposed an instrument with intuitive control mode and rigid frame for supporting the surgeon’s forearm via an arm-brace which is not very convenient during operation and Zahraee et al.14 proposed a motor-actuated hand-held instrument with bellow tubing, an improved multi-slider linkages structure. Among those high-dexterous instruments, the RealHand™ HD made by Novare15 and the Laparo-Angle™ produced by CambridgeEndo,16 using the improved multi-slider linkages structure with small size (5 mm in diameter),17 are the two most successful commercial instruments.

From those literatures and successful products, it can be found that cable-driven devices are preferred for medical instruments. Despite many obvious advantages of cable, such as it can make the instrument light in weight, compact in structure, and enable large range of motion, it is not without its problem. For this driven mode, some kind of mechanical constraint mechanism is usually required when needs to rotate about a specific axis. The rigid central link, which can direct the motion of the end-effector, is a good candidate relative to other structures. Taking advantages of both rigid links and cables, a hybrid-driven mode is chosen for designing a medical instruments.18,19

According to the preferences and feeling from surgeons, some requirements are very necessary to be taken into consideration when designing an instrument, such as high dexterity, intuitive, ergonomic actuation, user friendly, and low-cost. Although some instruments can meet the requirements of light and dexterous, they lack intuitive control, that is, the instruments do not accord with the lever principle and somehow in disagreement with our common sense.13

In this article, with the objective of satisfying the requirements of dexterity, intuitive control, simplicity, and low-cost, a novel manual medical instrument, named “Easy Grasp” is put forward and the optimization is elaborated.

sec.title: The novel hybrid-driven instrument
sec.p: Aiming to put it into effect, cable, link, universal joint, parallelogram, and isomorphism structure have been applied in the basic structure. Then, the detailed structure is optimally designed on the basis of the kinematic analysis together with the global conditioning index (GCI). To obtain GCI, the rotation workspace is analyzed based on theory of special orthogonal group. The prototype has been developed and its performance has been validated by laboratory experiments.

Figure 2 shows the prototype of the hybrid-driven multi-DoF manual instrument with an anthropocentric structure. The dexterous instrument can be used to perform precise and complex tasks such as suturing and knot-tying. The instrument is an intuitive control with one-to-one mapping structure (Figure 3) and turns out to be an inexpensive equipment for laparoscopic surgery. The instrument is a unique structure with hybrid driving system. Surgeons can operate comfortably and intuitively in that the instrument is designed according to the lever principle. When the end-in-hand (driver plate, DP) is downward, the end-effector (following plate, FP) will be upward. Figure 2.
Prototype of Easy Grasp.
Figure 3.
Intuitive control and one-to-one mapping between the surgeon and the tool.

The instrument is composed of two movable plates (DP and FP), four cables, one spine (a rigid center link), one handle, and a cylinder shell connected to the trocar (Figure 4). The cylinder-shaped spine connects the DP with the FP via universal joints. The four cables pass through the holes in the spine and form several parallelograms with DP and FP. During operation, the surgeon can hold the handle with one hand and manipulate the DP outside the abdomen with the other hand. When the DP is manipulated, cables are pulled and each micro-movement will be transmitted to the FP. The FP is attached to the tool as a follow-up unit as a result of the parallelogram constraint. The orientation of the FP is exactly the same as that of the DP, as shown in Figures 5 and 6. Owing to the wrist, the instrument can pitch, yaw, and roll inside the abdominal cavity. Due to the parallelograms and the universal joints, the wrist motion is intuitively controlled by cables and the spine. The roll motion is driven by the spine while the pitch and yaw motions are driven by cables. The maximum angle between the two jaws is 60∘ and the ranges of the pitch and yaw motions are both 60∘ ( [-30∘,30∘] ). Surgeons can finish suturing and knotting quickly and comfortably by the wrist-like joint within this range. Figure 4.
Overview of the instrument.
Figure 5.
Movements of the instrument.
Figure 6.
Corresponding postures of DP and FP.

sec.title: Structure matrix
sec.p: For the novel hybrid-driven instrument in Figure 4, the number of cables and the angle between them have to be determined in order to achieve practical configuration and optimum performance. In this section, the number of cables and the angle between neighboring cables are determined by kinematic analysis. The two parameters are determined together with the performance index and the instrument is designed optimally.

For a cable-driven mechanism, the cables can only provide tensile forces. Pushing on the moving platform is not feasible, which is analogous to grasping using frictionless point contacts. The special feature indicates that the theorems such as Caratheodory’s and Steinitz’s theorems that are applied to the grasping condition can also be used to analyze the cable mechanism. Such theorems can be used to determine the number of the cables in a cable-driven mechanism.20,21 For a force-closure cable-driven mechanism with n DoFs, Caratheodory’s theorem demonstrates that the number of cables is at least n and Steinitz’s theorem states that any number more than 2n is redundant. Thus, the number of cables must satisfy the inequality n+1≤ck≤2n , where ck represents the number of cables. As the roll motion is controlled by the spine, cables only control the instrument to implement pitch and yaw motions. From the above analysis, the range of the cable number is 3≤ck≤4 . For the integer ck, its possible value is 3 or 4.

On the basis of the theorem, several possible topological configurations of hybrid-driven mechanisms can be obtained. The circular shapes of DP and FP are determined by the requirements of laparoscopic surgery. Meanwhile, the tool motions should be corresponding to the surgeons’ operation, making the universal joint a proper selection. The two applicable configurations are shown in Figure 7. Figure 7.
Simplified model of three- and four-cable structures.

The geometric model for kinematic analysis and the arrangement of the cables in the two applicable configurations are shown in Figure 8. The plates should counteract the external wrench (WEX) produced by cutting or scissoring the tissue. The body frame B-xyz coincides with the fixed frame O-XYZ at initial configuration. Points B and O, attached on the center of the universal joint, are the center of the frames. Vector rai B and rai are the radius of connection of the cables to the DP in body frame and fixed frame, respectively. Vector rbi B and rbi are the radius of connection of the cables to the FP in body frame and fixed frame, respectively. rli is the vector of the ith cable. Assuming that the cables are symmetrical about the Y-axis and the angle between cable A1 and A2 is defined as θ. Figure 8.

sec.title: Rotation analysis
sec.p:
The rotation group is a natural manifold that satisfies the group axioms where the group operations are smooth, so it is a Lie group and called special orthogonal group (SO(3)) . Roughly speaking, a manifold is smooth figure or space and is said to be ‘patched’ by the different coordinate charts. In mathematics, a manifold is a topological space that is locally Euclidean. An arbitrary topology piece can be locally obtained by slightly rounding a small domain in an ordinary coordinate, manifold glues the domains. A tangent bundle (TSO(3)) is a union of the tangent spaces on the manifold (SO(3)) at its every point. The parameterization is the inverse of the coordinate chart. By overlapping the parameterizations, the manifold can be obtained.22,23 The relationship between manifold, parameterization, and coordinate chart is shown in Figure 9. Figure 9.
Chart and parameterization of a manifold.

When the rotation matrix is parameterized as R=Q(ui)=Q(ui1,ui2,ui3) , then the angular velocity can be extracted from the derivation of rotation matrix (2)ωL=vect(R·RT)=JL(ui)u·i where ωL is the angular velocity in the fixed frame, JL=[vect(∂Qui1QT)vect(∂Qui2QT)vect(∂Qui3QT)] and ui=[ui1ui2ui3]T the parameterization element.

There are many parameterization methods such as Euler angles (EA), matrix exponential (ME), and quaternions parameters.24 Among various parameterization methods, EA and ME are suitable for rotation analysis.24–26 The volume of rotation workspace is the integration measures of rotation matrix in the parameterization but does not depend on the parameterization. The integral over the set of the rotation is (3)N=∫SO(3)dV=∫SO(3)|det(JL)|dui1dui2dui3 where |det(JL)| is the volume element.

sec.title: Parameter optimization
sec.p: The kinematic performance of the mechanism can be measured in many ways. These measures include manipulability, smallest singular value, condition number, and isotropy.27 The condition number of the Jacobian matrix is one of the most suitable performance measures for evaluating the dexterity and singularity of mechanism.28 It is also used as an index for optimal design. However, since the condition number κ is a local performance measure and varies with the configuration of the mechanism, it cannot reflect the capabilities of the manipulator throughout the workspace.29 To overcome this drawback, Gosselin and Angeles proposed a global performance index which is termed as the GCI.30 It can be defined as GCI=M/N , where M=∫S(1/κ)dV and κ=‖J‖‖J-1‖=tr(JJT) .

Figure 11 shows the variation of the performance measure GCI versus θ. In Figure 11(a), the curve is symmetrical about 90° and the peak of the curve is at about 60° and 120°. Considering the practical application, θ should larger than 90°. In Figure 11(b), GCI first increases and then decreases with the increase of θ and takes the maximum value when θ is at about 90∘ . The smoother curve shows that the performance measure GCI of a four-cable structure is better than that of a three-cable one and the maximum value of GCI is greater. This indicates that the four-cable arrangement is more suitable for the structure. Figure 11.
Variation of GCI versus θ .

sec.title: Experiments
sec.p:
Experiments were carried out to evaluate the performance of the prototype, including the movements of the wrist-like joint, grasping task, suturing, and knot-tying tasks. In the experiments, a plastic human body model was used to simulate a patient lying on an operating table and a piece of foam plastic was used as the trocar. An intern held the handle with one hand and operated the DP with the other, as shown in Figure 12. It can be observed that the proposed instrument with the wrist-like joint is very dexterous and the intuitive control facilitates the operation. Then, force measurements were conducted to evaluate the mechanical property and an average grasping force of 2.2 N and rotational force of 14.5 N were obtained. It shows that the instrument has large enough force to finish the surgery tasks.31 The suturing and knot-tying tasks were performed after the intestine was placed inside the skeleton, as shown in Figures 13 and14, respectively. These operations were completed with ease and convenience. Figure 12.
Movements of the wrist-like joint with tip grasping suture needle.
Figure 13.
Suturing task.
Figure 14.
Knot-tying task.

The experimental results indicate that the novel manual instrument proposed in this article has large enough forces to finish the tasks in laparoscopic surgery. Its distinguished features, including the ergonomic structure, large workspace, intuitive control, enhanced dexterity, and easy operability, make it easy and comfortable for surgeons to complete the operation.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, a hybrid-driven manual instrument, Easy Grasp, is proposed and the prototype of the instrument is developed. Easy Grasp, the proposed instrument can be used to dexterously implement complex tasks in laparoscopic surgery, such as suturing and knot-tying. The instrument is an intuitive controllable and one-to-one mapping structure as a result of the constraints of the parallelogram structure and universal joints. To enhance the dexterity, a wrist-like structure is introduced into the design. The pitch and yaw motions are manually actuated via cables and the roll motion is realized via the spine. The rotation workspace of the wrist is obtained by ME parameterization. Based on Caratheodory’s and Steinitz’s theorems and GCI, the four-cable with 90∘ angular arrangement is chosen as the optimal. This proposed structure can be used as a fundamental for development of other similar manual instruments. Experiments show that the prototype is dexterous, intuitive, and ergonomic actuated. The simple structure and low manufacturing cost are the other two attractive features for commercialization. The instrument will be improved in both the structure and the performance based on feedback from surgeons. In the future, a smaller and lighter manual instrument will be developed.
